information.title: Structure
information.description: The Indian Judiciary consists of the Supreme Court at the apex, High Courts at the state level, and District Courts at the district level. The Supreme Court is the highest court of appeal and the guardian of the Constitution.

information.title: Supreme Court
information.description: The Supreme Court of India is the highest judicial forum and final court of appeal. It consists of the Chief Justice and 33 other judges. The Supreme Court has original, appellate, and advisory jurisdictions.

information.title: High Courts
information.description: Each state has a High Court, which is the highest court in the state. Some High Courts have jurisdiction over more than one state or union territory. High Courts have original and appellate jurisdictions in their respective states.

information.title: District Courts
information.description: District Courts are established by the state governments for each district or group of districts. They deal with both civil and criminal matters and are subordinate to the High Court of the state.

information.title: Judicial Review
information.description: The power of Judicial Review allows the judiciary to examine the constitutionality of legislative enactments and executive orders. This power helps maintain the supremacy of the Constitution.

information.title: Independence of Judiciary
information.description: The Constitution ensures the independence of the judiciary through various provisions, including security of tenure for judges, fixed salaries, and prohibition on discussion of judges' conduct in legislatures.
